In this vein, one prominent model used is the Idealized Sphere Model often applied to understand the basic geometry around which realistic simulations can center their parameters. This simplification assumes both the shape of the Earth/planet body itself and its distribution of mass follows perfect symmetry along all axes passing through the geometric center of said sphere. Such assumptions facilitate certain calculations regarding gravitational interactions and internal dynamics because it reduces complex three-dimensional problems into mathematically solvable forms. direct_answer.text:
To simplify this into a basic explanation suitable for educational purposes around ideals typical in teaching geology, especially considering plate tectonics theory and seismic activity caused by mantle convection currents beneath ocean ridges:

Imagine we can view Earth as wrapped in a giant ball made mostly of rock, which includes several large plates floating on molten material deeper in the middle layer known as the mantle. These plates move very slowly relative to one another because heat rising from the center makes parts of the interior less dense than others, creating movement resembling boiling water bubbles moving through it. This hotspot creation leads sometimes to volcanoes erupting, forming new islands, mountains, etc. It also causes sea floor spreading happening usually at mid-ocean ridges — places where magma pushes up and creates new oceanic crust pushing older materials away sideways like conveyor belts in slow motion!
